abstract.p: The newly available confocallight microscopes produce series of aligned images that implicitly constitute volumes. This would directly provide scientists with the capability for volumetric study of the biological world at high spatial resolutionexcept that methods to effectively visualize volume data have been insufficiently rapid and flexible. We have developed software research tools to fill that need. In the process, we have found that excellent reconstructions could be made from serial sections acquired using a charge-coupled device and a conventional light microscope (modified after Inoul [ l ]). Brightfield images of high-contrast subjects (such as golgi-impregnated or horseradish peroxidase labeled cells) were reconstructed crisply, as were some fluorescently labeled cells. Volume microscopy now should be within reach of, and of use to, a wider range of scientists.

div.head: Standard imaging methods in light microscopy collapse
div.p: an exmded optical depth of field into two dimensions. In some cases this can be advantageous, however the great majority of biologically interesting microscopic samples a~ intrinsically three-dimensional. Binocular (stereo) imaging can broaden the viewpoint a bit, but stereo explores only a limited range of angles near the optical axis. Until recently. fully arbihiuily oriented three-dimensional representations of microscopic specimens were unachievable except by fecourse to extremely laborious methods.

The confocal microscope has dramatically altered this situation. Confocal optics reduce the depth of field that conaibutes to each image of a series, by geometrically rejecting out-of-focus information (via spinning disks [2] or laser scanning techniques [3,4,51). This gene" serial sections, each containing information derived h m very narrow levels of focuswhich improves resolution both laterally and axially. Unfortunately, however, each single section is usually less interpretable than a conventional microscopic image, because it contains less of the overall structure being studied. In addition, many more sections are required in order to account for an adequately sampled total volume. These stringent limitations and demands require powerful data visualization techniques to compensate for them. Fortunately, one approach based on concurrent advances in computer graphics workstations and rendering algorithms (in particular, a technique known as volume rendering) is proving to be an intuitively straightforward and visually effective approach for accurate reconstruction of volumetric microscopy data.

div.head: Volume Rendering
div.p: Volume rendering is a method for directly visualizing the distribution of some property in three-dimensional space, by projecting and compositing an array of volumetric samples (voxels) into a planar image on the computer screen [6,7]. In contrast to surface extraction methods, which do not display the full data, volume rendering methods preserve the original resolution and avoid interpretation artifacts that result when surface methods are applied to complex or noisy data [81.

However, because such rendering algorithms must exhaustively traverse the entire volume of data (comprising many millions of voxels), volume rendering taxes even the most powerN (and expensive) of computer workstations. Hence, this approach has been neither practical nor affordable for most microscopists.

To remove these obstacles, we created software (Voxel-Viewm, Vital Images) optimized to run efficiently on moderately-priced, general-purpose graphics workstations (IRIS 4 D series, Silicon Graphics Computer Systems). Rendering speeds of up to 4 million voxels/second have been achieved, making it possible to render typical microscope data sets in a few seconds. In addition, the user interface has been designed to promote interactivity and easy access to the necessary rendering techniques.

div.head: Effects of differing light sources
div.p: As is well known, the characteristics of the microscope's light source can dramatically impact the quality of the images obtained. Most transmitted light microscopes have uneven transmitted illumination, caused by spatial inhomogeneity in the heated filament. This variation in light intensity across the image usually is reduced by means of a ground-glass diffuser, but inevitably persists to a significant extent. In practice this prevents one from using the full numerical aperture of the system, and this translates directly into loss of spatial resolution in all dimensions (most notably along the optical axis). However, by interposing an ess-shaped single-strand quartz fiber optic light pipe between the light source and the microscope, one can dramatidy improve the uniformity of the lightand thereby make use of more of the system's numerical aperture [1,10]. We illustrate in Figure 3 the effect that a diffuser or light pipe has on composited transmitted-light images.
